file_metadata.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]
file_metadata.title: Interferon-Gamma Stimulated Murine Macrophages In Vitro: Impact of Ionic Composition and Osmolarity

chunks.text: Injections of osmolytes are promising immunomodulatory treatments, but their mechanisms are not fully understood. This study aimed to clarify the anti-inflammatory role of potassium and decouple the effects of ionic strength, species, and osmolarity on macrophage biology.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the anti-inflammatory effects of potassium and the influence of ionic properties on macrophage biology.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: RAW 264.7 murine macrophages were encapsulated in 3D hydrogels and activated with interferon-gamma (IFNγ). Gene and protein profiles were analyzed after exposure to hyperosmolar potassium gluconate, sodium gluconate, or sucrose.
chunks.chunk_summary: Macrophages were encapsulated, activated, and exposed to hyperosmolar solutions for analysis.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: All hyperosmolar treatments suppressed pro-inflammatory markers (NOS-2, TNFα, MCP-1) and increased IL-6 and VEGF mRNA. Ionic osmolytes had a greater effect than sucrose, with IL-6 mRNA most affected. Potassium treatment resulted in the lowest NOS-2 and MCP-1 levels and limited IL-6 release.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperosmolar treatments suppressed inflammation and increased IL-6 and VEGF, with ionic osmolytes showing a stronger effect and potassium specifically reducing NOS-2, MCP-1, and IL-6.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Osmolyte composition, ionic strength, and osmolarity influence therapeutic outcomes. Further research is needed to understand their impact on cell biology, including macrophage functions, intracellular osmolyte composition, and membrane potentials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Further research is needed to fully understand the impact of osmolyte properties on cell biology and therapeutic outcomes.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Chronically altered immune systems and local tissue immune-cell landscapes are relevant in various diseases. Macrophages play a key role in inflammation and wound healing. Modulating macrophage behavior is a promising therapeutic strategy.
chunks.chunk_summary: Macrophages are important in disease and wound healing, and modulating their behavior is therapeutically relevant.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Modulating biophysical parameters through osmolyte injections has shown promise in treating various conditions. This study aims to integrate knowledge from these approaches for improved therapies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Modulating biophysical parameters with osmolytes is a promising therapeutic approach.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Prior research has shown that specific biophysical inputs can alter cellular function, but the mechanisms are complex. Sodium ions can trigger macrophage chemotaxis and modulate inflammation and wound healing, while potassium ions can suppress the NLRP3 inflammasome and IL-1β production.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biophysical factors like sodium and potassium ions can influence macrophage function and inflammation.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Ions act as both chemical and electrical messengers, influencing enzymatic activity and membrane potential. Transmembrane voltage potential (Vmem) regulates cell state and various cellular functions.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ions influence cell function through chemical and electrical signaling, including effects on membrane potential.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Previous studies have often investigated biophysical parameters in isolation. This study aims to investigate the combined effects of ionic species, ionic strength, osmolarity, and Vmem on macrophage function, hypothesizing that potassium treatment has anti-inflammatory and pro-resolving effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the combined effects of biophysical parameters on macrophage function, hypothesizing an anti-inflammatory role for potassium.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Previous work has shown that hyperosmolar potassium gluconate suppresses pro-inflammatory features of chondrocytes and macrophages. This study aims to provide further evidence for the anti-inflammatory effect of potassium and decouple the influence of osmolyte composition, ionic strength, osmolarity, and Vmem on macrophage biology.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study builds on previous work to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of potassium and the influence of biophysical factors on macrophage biology.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: PEGDA hydrogels were fabricated with specific molecular weight, concentration, and RGDS concentration. RAW 264.7 macrophages were cultured in 3D hydrogels to minimize confounding factors. Cells were activated with IFNγ and exposed to hyperosmolar treatments (KG, NaG, Suc) for 24 hours.
chunks.chunk_summary: Macrophages were cultured in 3D hydrogels, activated with IFNγ, and exposed to hyperosmolar treatments.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: mRNA was isolated, and RT-qPCR was performed to evaluate gene expression. Total DNA was quantified to assess cell viability and normalize protein levels. Western blots and multiplex immunoassays were used to measure protein expression.
chunks.chunk_summary: Gene and protein expression were analyzed using RT-qPCR, Western blots, and multiplex immunoassays.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Membrane potential was measured using DiSBAC2(3), a voltage-sensitive dye. Fluorescence intensity changes indicated depolarization or hyperpolarization. Statistical analyses were performed using t-tests or post hoc tests.
chunks.chunk_summary: Membrane potential changes were measured using a voltage-sensitive dye and analyzed statistically.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: IFNγ, but not LPS, activated macrophages in 3D hydrogels. IFNγ increased TNFα and IL-6 mRNA expression, confirming a classically activated state suitable for investigating hyperosmolar treatment effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: IFNγ successfully activated macrophages in 3D hydrogels, while LPS did not.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: All hyperosmolar treatments reduced NOS-2 protein levels without affecting cell viability. Potassium treatment resulted in the lowest NOS-2 levels compared to sodium gluconate and sucrose.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperosmolar treatments reduced NOS-2 protein, with potassium having the strongest effect.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Hyperosmolar treatments reduced MCP-1 levels, with potassium further reducing MCP-1 compared to sucrose. Sodium gluconate uniquely increased IL-6 secretion, while potassium prevented this increase. TNFα and VEGF levels were unaffected.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperosmolar treatments affected secreted protein levels, with potassium specifically reducing MCP-1 and preventing IL-6 increase by sodium gluconate.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: All hyperosmolar treatments reduced pro-inflammatory marker mRNA expression (NOS-2, MCP-1, TNFα), with potassium showing the strongest effect. Ionic osmolytes increased IL-6 mRNA, while all treatments increased VEGF mRNA. Sodium gluconate increased VEGF and IL-6 mRNA more than potassium or sucrose.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperosmolar treatments reduced pro-inflammatory gene expression and increased IL-6 and VEGF mRNA, with potassium and sodium gluconate showing specific effects.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Potassium gluconate depolarized, sucrose hyperpolarized, and sodium gluconate did not affect macrophage membrane potential. This suggests that membrane potential may not be the primary determinant of the observed functional changes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Different hyperosmolar treatments had distinct effects on membrane potential, suggesting it may not be the primary driver of functional changes.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: This study aimed to investigate the effects of potassium and decouple the influence of osmolyte properties on macrophage function. Potassium treatment suppressed NOS-2 and MCP-1 and limited IL-6 secretion, supporting its anti-inflammatory role.
chunks.chunk_summary: Potassium treatment showed anti-inflammatory effects by suppressing NOS-2, MCP-1, and IL-6.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: The results suggest that potassium can regulate macrophage metabolism and function independently of NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition. Hyperosmolar treatments decreased pro-inflammatory markers and increased IL-6 and VEGF mRNA, consistent with therapeutic applications but contrasting with some previous studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperosmolar treatments showed anti-inflammatory effects, consistent with therapeutic uses but contrasting some prior research.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: The distinct effects of different osmolytes on membrane potential suggest that it may not be the major determinant of macrophage function. However, further investigation with more quantitative methods is needed.
chunks.chunk_summary: Membrane potential may not be the primary driver of observed functional changes, but further research is needed.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Ionic osmolytes shared certain effects compared to nonionic sucrose, suggesting a role for ionic strength in macrophage function. Further research is needed to decouple the effects of ionic strength and osmolarity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ionic strength may play a role in macrophage function, independent of osmolarity.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: The study has limitations regarding the number of experimental groups and end point analyses, which may affect the interpretation of some findings. Future work will include more comprehensive analyses, primary cell types, and in vivo models.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study has limitations that will be addressed in future research.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Osmolyte composition, osmolarity, and ionic strength all impact macrophage biology. Future research will further investigate the impact of biophysical cues on cell biology to improve hyperosmolar-based therapies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biophysical factors influence macrophage biology, and further research will refine hyperosmolar therapies.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]

chunks.text: Thompson et al. (2015) found that lithium chloride prevents IL-1β-induced cartilage degradation. Bratton et al. (2007) discussed hyperosmolar therapy.
chunks.topic: References related to osmolarity and inflammation
chunks.chunk_summary: References cited relate to osmolarity, inflammation, and cartilage degradation.
chunks.authors: ["Joshua Erndt-Marino, PhD", "Daniel J. Yeisley, BS", "Hongyu Chen, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD", "David L. Kaplan, PhD", "Marian S. Hahn, PhD"]
